definition: abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]

sentences.english: An imperial edict is a writ in the name of an emperor.
sentences.chinese: 詔書是以皇帝名義發佈指令的專用文書。

sentences.english: I have received a summons, and I dare not disobey it.
sentences.chinese: 我已收到了詔書，我不敢違抗。

sentences.english: At that day, he read out the imperial abdication edict and ended the morning court early.
sentences.chinese: 那天的段思英宣讀完退位詔書之後，就早早的退朝了。

definition: Western Jin dynasty 西晋 historian, author of History of the Three Kingdoms 三國志|三国志
Zhang Zhidong (1837-1909), prominent politician in late Qing
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
Emperor Wen of Han (202-157 BC), fourth Han emperor, personal name Liu Heng 劉恆|刘恒[Liu2 Heng2], reigned 180-157 BC
court examination, the top grade imperial exam
Jiangling county in Jingzhou 荊州|荆州[Jing1 zhou1], Hubei
call in (one's subordinates)/summon (an envoy of a foreign country) to an interview
Zhu Qizhen, personal name of sixth and eighth Ming emperor Zhengtong 正統|正统[Zheng4 tong3], afterwards Tianshun Emperor 天順|天顺[Tian1 shun4] (1427-1464), reigned 1435-1449 and 1457-1464
